facts.text: The assessee firm is engaged in the supply of foreign cotton to textile mills among other places in South India on the basis of the import licences issued to the mills authorising import of foreign cotton by them.

anchor.surface_text: According to them the firm is engaged in the supply of foreign companyton to textile mills among other places in South India on the basis of the import licences issued to the nulls authorising import of foreign companyton by them.

facts.text: The mills make enquiries with the firm as regards the quality of cotton they required, the period during which they would be supplied, the price and other particulars.

anchor.surface_text: The mills make enquiries with the firm as regards the quality of companyton they required, , the period during which they would be supplied, the price and other particulars and on getting these enquiries the appellant firm contacts the foreign suppliers in Egypt, Sudan or America for ascer-- taining whether they could supply the companyton required.

facts.text: The firm contacts the foreign suppliers in Egypt, Sudan or America for ascertaining whether they could supply the cotton required.

facts.text: If the offers received are found acceptable the firm enters into contract with the various mills concerned and immediately thereafter accepts the offer made by the foreign suppliers.

arguments.claim: This case falls within the rule laid down in K. Khosla & Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes

The appellant therein, imported certain goods from Belgium in order to fulfil contracts with certain buyers in India.

arguments.claim: The respondents were precluded from selling the goods to anybody other than the mills even if the clause had not been there

arguments.claim: A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of the import only if the sale or purchase either occasions such import or is effected by a transfer of documents of title to the goods before the goods have crossed the customs frontiers of India

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 5 2  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, which says A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of the import of the goods into the territory of India only if the sale or purchase either occasions such import or is effected by a transfer of documents of title to the goods before the goods have crossed the customs frontiers of India.

holdings.text: This case clearly falls within the rule laid down by this Court in K. Khosla & Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, where sales were held to occasion import and be exempt under Section 5(2) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956

anchor.surface_text: From the facts set out above it is clear that this case clearly falls within the rule laid down by this Court in K. Khosla Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1 . The appellant therein, imported certain goods from Belgium in order to fulfil contracts with certain buyers in India. The question arose whether the, sales effected in this country occasioned the import. This Court came to the conclusion that the sales in question occasioned the import and as such it is exempt under Sec. 5 2  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, which says A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of the import of the goods into the territory of India only if the sale or purchase either occasions such import or is effected by a transfer of documents of title to the goods before the goods have crossed the customs frontiers of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted facts show firm contracted with mills before foreign suppliers using mills' licences, acted as agent, goods destined exclusively for mills, similar to Khosla where import to fulfil buyer contracts occasioned import

holdings.text: The facts of this case are similar to those found in Khosla's case and the distinction that there were two sales here unlike one there is not accepted

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Sayed Mohammed tried to distinguish Khoslas case from the present case on the plea that in Khoslas case there was only one sale whereas in the present case there were two sales. We are unable to accept this contention as correct. From the facts set out above, it is clear that the facts of this case are similar to those found in Khoslas case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall transaction structure identical to Khosla despite number of sales; import solely to fulfil contracts with specific mills

holdings.text: The rule laid down in Coffee Board case is inapplicable to the present case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Coffee Board involved purchases preparatory to export not occasioning it, unlike here where sales directly occasioned import; Court distinguished Khosla but affirmed its principle

holdings.text: The clause in the letter of authority must be read as a part of the contract entered into between the respondents and the mills

anchor.surface_text: This submission, though in a technical sense may be correct, has really no substance because, as could be seen from the letter of authority issued by the Government that, one of the conditions of the letter of authority was, to quote the words of that letter The person or firm in whose favour it has been issued, will act purely as an agent of the licensee and the goods imported will be the property of the licence-holder both at the time, of clearance through the Customs and subsequent thereto. The licence-holder will have to ensure that the goods on importation will be delivered to him and shall not be disposed of otherwise. ... This clause must be read as a part of the contract entered into between the respondents and the mills.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter of authority conditions integral due to import control regime governing the transaction; firm acts as agent, goods property of licensee

holdings.text: The respondents were precluded from selling the goods to anybody other than the mills even if the clause had not been there

anchor.surface_text: Even if this clause had not been there, there would have been no difficulty in coming to the conclusion that the respondents were precluded from selling the goods to anybody other than the mills to whom the users import licence had been granted. From the facts set out above it is obvious that the respondents could not have sold the goods to anybody other than the, licence-holders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Import licences and regulations ensure goods for specific licensees only; diversion prohibited by scheme of import control

precedents.citation: K. Khosla Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1 .

anchor.surface_text: K. Khosla Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1 . The appellant therein, imported certain goods from Belgium in order to fulfil companytracts with certain buyers in India. The question arose whether the, sales effected in this companyntry occasioned the import. This Court came to the companyclusion that the sales in question occasioned the import and as such it is exempt under Sec. 5 2  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956,

precedents.case_name: K. Khosla Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes
precedents.cited_proposition: sales of goods imported to fulfil contracts with buyers in India occasion the import and are exempt under Sec. 5(2) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
precedents.cited_holding: the sales in question occasioned the import

precedents.citation: Coffee Board, Bangalore v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer, Madras and Another 1 .

anchor.surface_text: Coffee Board, Bangalore v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer, Madras and Another 1 . The facts of that case briefly stated, are as follows The Coffee Board auctioned certain quantities of companyfee for the purpose of being sold in foreign companyntries. The purchasers of those lots were required to export that quantity of companyfee to one or the other of the foreign companyntries mentioned in the sale numberice.

precedents.case_name: Coffee Board, Bangalore v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer, Madras and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: purchases of coffee auctioned by Coffee Board for export, where purchasers were required to export, did not occasion export
precedents.cited_holding: the purchases in question were purchases for the purpose of export and the same did number occasion export

anchor.surface_text: From the facts set out above it is clear that this case clearly falls within the rule laid down by this Court in K. Khosla Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1 . The appellant therein, imported certain goods from Belgium in order to fulfil contracts with certain buyers in India. The question arose whether the, sales effected in this country occasioned the import. This Court came to the conclusion that the sales in question occasioned the import and as such it is exempt under Sec. 5 2  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, which says A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of the import of the goods into the territory of India only if the sale or purchase either occasions such import or is effected by a transfer of documents of title to the goods before the goods have crossed the customs frontiers of India.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Sayed Mohammed tried to distinguish Khoslas case from the present case on the plea that in Khoslas case there was only one sale whereas in the present case there were two sales. We are unable to accept this contention as correct. From the facts set out above, it is clear that the facts of this case are similar to those found in Khoslas case.
